thesis: Constraints-first: current 12-name allocation satisfies max position (<=12%) and max sector (<=25%) while staying diversified across 7 sectors using verified sector classifications.
Quality + momentum balance: core exposure to large-cap compounders (MSFT, NVDA, AAPL, AVGO) is balanced by cyclicals (CVX, DE) and defensive growth (LLY, UNH).
30-day stability: avoiding turnover reduces idiosyncratic event risk and execution noise for a weekly-rebalanced paper model when no incremental, tool-verified catalyst advantage is available today.
risks: Factor crowding: Information Technology leadership could reverse quickly on valuation or macro-rate shocks over a 30-day window.
Single-name event risk: earnings/guidance or regulatory surprises can dominate short-horizon outcomes for any of these mega-caps.
Cyclicals whipsaw: Energy (CVX) and Industrials (DE) can retrace sharply if commodity/macro expectations change.

If any single holding’s weight drifts above 12% at the next weekly checkpoint, trim back to <=12% and reallocate proportionally to underweight sectors.
trade_of_the_day.why_now: Over a 6–18 month lens, the portfolio maintains exposure to durable cash-flow compounding in mega-cap technology (software and semis) while retaining real-economy cyclicality (energy and machinery) and structurally strong health care demand. This mix aims to participate in continued AI/compute capex and productivity themes without breaching concentration limits, and it keeps optionality if leadership rotates across sectors.
